Graphical abstract We report a novel lignosulfonate-based heterogeneous sulfonic acid catalyst (LF) which offered high yields of monosaccharides (75–98%) in hydrolysis of polysaccharides, such as cellobiose, maltose, d-melezitose, sucrose, inulin, and starch. Specific activity in cellobiose hydrolysis was 5.6±0.3mol glucose per mol SO3H. Kinetic analysis showed that the apparent activation energy of cellobiose hydrolysis over the LF catalyst is 98.5kJmol−1, which was less than 110–138kJmol−1 for mineral acids, organic acid homogeneous catalysts or grafted sulfonic acids. The catalyst was recycled by filtration and reused four times in cellobiose hydrolysis without apparent loss of catalytic activity. NMR characterization suggests that the better accessibility of cellobiose to SO3H sites and multiple bindings of hydroxyls of cellobiose on COOH and OH sites may account for its superior performance. This is a new method of utilizing pulp industry waste as sulfonic acid precursor; otherwise sulfonation process is required for preparing heterogeneous sulfonic acid catalysts. Keywords Lignosulfonate Catalyst Hydrolysis Cellulose Cellobiose 1 Introduction Biomass conversion to chemicals has garnished great interests in recent years. Glycosidic bond hydrolysis (GBH) reaction is a crucial step for conversion of biomass polymer to biochemicals and biofuels through sugar-based platform [1–9]. Acid and enzyme are among the most common catalysts for hydrolyzing cellulose into glucose [10,11]. In recent years, recyclable solid acids for cellulose hydrolysis have attracted great attentions [12–21]. However, achieving high selectivity and activity still remains a challenging task. This is mainly because cellulose is a class of multihydroxyl molecules, which are reluctant to be adsorbed to a single active site [15]. Therefore the hydrolysis reaction was usually conducted under fierce conditions. We think that a good catalyst should have spacially separated but synergetic sites for cellulose-binding and hydrolysis reaction, respectively [22–24]. The binding site is responsible for associating cellulose, while the catalytic site is for hydrolyzing glycosidic bonds of cellulose chain. Up to the present, the related studies are still limited [5,12]. We turn to proton-exchanged lignosulfonates as catalysts that bear both SO3H, COOH and OH. Lignosulfonate is a derived product of lignin via the sulfite process and contains sulfonic acid groups at aliphatic carbons via CS bonds [25]. It is currently disposed as waste into nature (black liquor) or combusted, causing pollution. Its values are greatly neglected. In catalytic conversion of lignosulfonate, high content of sulfur (3–5%wt) remains as an obstacle to its valorization into value-added chemicals. On the other hand, many studies sulfonated carbon supports in order to generate sulfonic acid group as acid sites. In this regard, we think lignosulfonate can be a good precursor for sulfonic acid catalyst. First, lignin and saccharide units are inter-connected with multiple bonds in plant cell, and therefore their structures are complementary, which enable them accessible to each other through multiple binding sites. Second, different to other supports, such as carbon and oxides, lignosulfonate is hydrophilic, possessing affinity to water and hydroxyl bonds, which is beneficial for substrate adsorption. Lignosulfonates are soluble in water. In order to be used as catalyst, they should be heterogenized and proton-exchanged. We used phenol–formaldehyde condensation of lignosulfonate and formalin in diluted sulfuric acid to prepare several polymerized and insoluble sulfonic acid catalysts. The surface area of these materials was controlled by hard silica template in order to expose more sulfonic sites. These polymers have shown excellent catalytic activities in hydrolyzing disaccharide, oligosaccharide and polysaccharides, such as cellobiose, maltose, d-melezitose, sucrose, inulin, and starch to monosaccharides, such as glucose and fructose, with 75–98% yields. The catalysts can be separated and reused for several times. We believe that the method may increase the value of lignosulfonate, and is also a valuable addition to the family of solid sulfonic acid, which have found many applications in catalysis, adsorption and ion exchange. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and chemicals All reagents were of analytical grade and used as purchased without further purification. Sodium lignosulfonate is purchased from ABCR GmbH & Co. KG (abcr AB137729). Formalin (38% formaldehyde, methanol-free) was purchased from Tianjin Kemel Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. H-β, H-mordenites, H-ZSM-5, sulfonated zirconia and titania were purchased from Taiyuan Xinjida Chemical Co., Ltd. Polysaccharides (cellobiose, maltose, d-melezitose, sucrose, starch, inulin, crystalline cellulose, filter paper, corn cob, ethyl cellulose) were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Corporation. Nanoparticle silica (NS-1 and NS-2) was purchased from Dalian Snowchemical. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The lignosulfonate-based catalyst was prepared through phenol–formaldehyde condensation reaction. Typically, 3.0g of lignosulfonate was dissolved in 5.2mL water in a 100-mL flask. About 1.2mL formalin (formaldehyde 15%wt of lignosulfonate) was added to the above solution. Under magnetic stirring, 2.7mL concentrated HCl (37%) was added. The concentration of HCl was 3M in the final mixture. The flask was then immersed in a 90̊C oil bath under stirring. The reaction was continued for 6h. The solid was filtered out, and dried at 110̊C for 6h, and was then crushed to 80 mesh particle. The sample was exchanged in 2M H2SO4 for 2h, filtered out, washed to neutral and dried at 110̊C for 6h. The sample is designated as LF-A. The preparation procedure of the LF-B and LF-C catalysts is the same with that of the LF-A, except adding a certain amount of silica balls (diameters of 15–17 and 200–300nm, respectively) as template. The weight of template is 10%wt of lignosulfonate. After the samples were proton-exchanged, these samples were immersed in 5% HF solution for 12h to remove silica, followed by filtering and drying. The FT-IR spectra were measured with Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrometer with 30 scan at a resolution of 4cm−1. Specific surface areas were measured by N2 adsorption at 77K using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method (BET) over Autosorb 6AG (Quantachrome Instruments). Sulfur content was measured by CHNS annlyzer (Vario EL cube). 2.3 Titration of SO3H, COOH, and OH The acid–base titration method was modified from literature [15]. In the first test, about 0.1g of catalyst was put into 20mL NaCl (2M) solution. The mixture was sonicated for 1h and was centrifuged. The solution was titrated with 8mM NaOH solution with phenolphthalein as indicator. The NaOH solution was pre-calibrated with standard potassium acid phthalate solution. The molar amount of SO3H per gram catalyst can be obtained ( M SO 3 H ). In the following titration, about 0.05g catalyst was put in 20mL 8mM NaOH solution. The mixture was sonicated for 1h and was centrifuged. The filtrate was titrated with 1mM potassium acid phthalate solution with phenolphthalein as indicator. Therefore, the total amount of SO3H, COOH and OH was obtained ( M SO 3 H , COOH and OH ). In the third titration, about 0.05g catalyst was put into 20mL 80mM NaHCO3 solution. The mixture was sonicated for 1h and was centrifuged. The filtrate was titrated with 0.1M HCl solution with phenolphthalein as indicator. Through this method, the amount of SO3H and COOH can be determined ( M SO 3 H and COOH ). The amount of OH (M OH) was determined by subtracting ( M SO 3 H and COOH ) from ( M SO 3 H , COOH and OH ). 2.4 Catalytic reactions and kinetic analysis Catalytic reactions were conducted in a 25mL Teflon-lined autoclave reactor under stirring. Typically, 0.1g of polysaccharide and 0.1g of catalyst were mixed in 5.0mL deionized water. The reactor was then sealed and placed in a preheated copper mantle at desired temperature. The reaction was continued for a desired time. After reaction, the catalyst was filtered out using a membrane filter. About 2μL of the filtrate was collected and analyzed in liquid chromatography (Waters 2695, XBridge™ C18 column (5μm, 4.6mm×150mm); flowing phase acetonitrile: water=75:25 (v/v); flowing rate 1mLmin−1; column temperature 30̊C). The yields of glucose and fructose were quantified using internal calibration curves obtained by calibrating several known concentration of standard substances. The definition of monosaccharide yield is given as the following. For polymer cellulose, the molar amount of glucose units is calculated by assuming the cellulose formula as (C6H10O5) n . Yield of glucose or fructose=(molar amount of glucose or fructose obtained/total molar amount of glucose or fructose units in the added polysaccharides)×100%. After reaction, the catalyst was filtered out, washed with water, and dried. The recycling reactions were conducted in the same procedure with the fresh catalyst. Since the catalyst amount lost about 10% in each run, the initial reaction was scaled up to 2 times, i.e. 0.2g of cellobiose and 0.2g of catalyst in 10mL water. The other conditions were same. The amounts of cellobiose and water were adjusted accordingly in next run. Kinetic analysis of cellobiose hydrolysis was conducted with LF-A catalyst. About 0.1mL of reaction mixture was collected at intervals and was analyzed with liquid chromatography. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the LF samples We prepared three catalysts by direct polymerization (LF-A), templated with silica (diameter 15–17nm) (LF-B) and silica (200–300nm) (LF-C), respectively (Fig. 1 ). The vibration bands at 1035cm−1 (SO3 − stretching) and 1215cm−1 (OSO stretching in SO3H) in the FT-IR spectra indicate that the materials contain SO3H groups (Fig. 2 ) [15]. The vibration at 1712cm−1 indicates the presence of COOH groups. The broad band at 3421cm−1 is assigned to an overtone of the bending mode of OH linked with the neighbor oxygen or sulfuric acid by hydrogen bonds, indicating these acidic groups are located in close proximity [14]. The bands at 2847 and 2943cm−1 are assigned to the stretching vibration of CH2 , indicating that the phenol units are linked by methylene groups from formaldehyde. The vibration bands at 1460, 1502 and 1615cm−1 are the characteristics of benzene rings. Independent of preparation methods, peak positions and intensities do not change too much, inferring that all these samples share the same local bond environments. And there is no change in peak positions between the used and fresh catalyst indicating the structure of catalyst is the same with the fresh catalyst after reaction. These catalysts have different specific surface area as evidenced by N2 adsorption (S BET). S BET of LF-A is 25m2 g−1 with BJH pore diameter 2–3nm (Fig. 3 ). Polymerizations templated with silica (15–17nm) and silica (200–300nm) generate pores of 3–5nm (LF-B) and 6–8nm (LF-C) with increased surface area of 53m2 g−1 (LF-B) and 107m2 g−1 (LF-C) after removing templates (Fig. S1). The diameters of these pores are much smaller than the corresponding silica templates. This may be caused by pore contraction since the polymer is composed of flexible organic framework. The three samples exhibit similar surface concentrations of each acidic group determined by different base titrants [15]. Surface concentrations of each acidic group are determined by different base titrants. The measurement results are given in Table 1 . These samples exhibit similar acidity for each group. The total acidity is about 2mmolg−1. The concentration of SO3H is about 1mmolg−1, corresponding about 3.2% (wt/wt) sulfur content of lignosulfonate. This result infers that all acidic groups in these resins are accessible to titrants, and the polymerization network is open. The sulfur contents were slightly higher than SO3H, suggesting that some of sulfur species was not acidic. 3.2 Catalytic reactions Cellobiose is a disaccharide which is soluble in water and consists of two glucose units linked by 1→4-β-glycosidic bond. It is commonly used as a model compound of cellulose. In theory hydrolysis of one cellobiose gives two glucoses. Catalytic results show the LF catalysts are more active than common acid catalysts (Fig. 4 ). No other byproducts, such as levulinic acid, were detected, but these products were found over other acid catalysts, such H-β, H-mordenites, H-ZSM-5, sulfonated zirconia and titania, well agreeing with the literatures [27]. One of the reasons for insufficient activity of the other solid acids is that unlike the LF catalysts, they do not have dedicated substrate-binding sites for associating cellobiose to the catalyst surface, and they do have acidic sites (Lewis or Brönsted acid sites) for further converting of glucose. It is hypothesized that cellobiose is more preferably adsorbed onto the LF surface compared to glucose because the former has more binding locations (hydroxyl groups) than the latter. Glucose leaves catalyst as soon as it is generated to free the binding sites for new cellobiose molecule. We note that although sulfuric acid has been reported as active catalyst for cellulose to glucose, the catalyst can also catalyze the conversion of glucose to byproducts. As a result, the glucose yield is low. The best glucose yield of 95% is achieved over the LF-C catalyst (Fig. 4). Reaction over Amberlyst-15 gives slightly lower result (88%). However, if one considers the specific activity (mol of generated glucose/mol SO3H group in reaction), the value for all LF catalysts is about 5.6±0.5molmol−1, which is higher than 1.2molmol−1 for Amberlyst-15. The higher specific activity can be explained by that (i) the lignosulfonate-based catalysts have complementary structure with cellobiose, (ii) the catalyst surface is highly hydrophilic with stronger affinity for cellobiose, and (iii) the synergetic effect invoked by SO3H, COOH and OH in close proximity promotes the adsorption-activation of cellobiose through multiple site bindings. It is reported that either COOH (pKa ∼5) or OH (pKa 9.9) alone was inactive for cellobiose hydrolysis due to insufficient acidic strength [28]. We believe that SO3H groups function as catalytic domains in hydrolysis of glycosidic bonds, and COOH and OH groups function as binding domains for cellobiose. The geometrical distance of these groups is in a 1–2nm scale, comparable to the size of cellobiose. Hydrolysis starts with cellobiose hydroxyls binding on COOH and OH groups (total density 1.2mmolg−1) with noncovalent interaction, leading to surface concentration. The SO3H groups functions as acid sites, protonating the glycosidic oxygen and generating cyclic oxocarbenium ion concomitantly with bond cleavage. After a rapid addition of water, free glucose and a proton are liberated. 3.3 NMR characterization Fig. 5 shows the 1H NMR spectra of cellobiose and its mixture with lignosulfonic acid in DMSO-d 6. Lignosulfonic acid was obtained by proton-exchanging lignosulfonate. Use of lignosulfonic acid as a model catalyst instead of LF catalyst was required for homogeneous shimming in collecting NMR spectra. This method, although not strongly, give some hints of substrate-catalyst interaction as illustrated by proton signals of hydroxyls ranging from 4.5–6.8ppm. When lignosulfonic acid is added into cellobiose/DMSO-d 6 solution, the peaks of hydroxyls in the shift of 4.4–5.5ppm merge together, and are combined into three broad peaks. The observed deshielding as indicated by significant broadening of proton resonances in hydroxyls suggests hydroxyls electronically interact with COOH or OH groups, perhaps via hydrogen bonding [29–31], whereas very little change is observed for the peaks of methylene and methine in the cellobiose backbone (shift 4.1–4.4ppm). 3.4 Theoretical calculation Binding functions of COOH and OH groups on cellobiose is supported by theoretical calculation (see supporting information) [32]. When these two groups act as binding sites to attract cellobiose to SO3H sites, two hydrogen bonds (1.94 and 1.832Å) with cellobiose may be formed with the binding energy of LF catalyst is −20.1kcalmol−1, which is lower than 12.3kcalmol−1 of Amberlyst-15 with cellobiose. Both experimental and theoretical results may suggest COOH and OH groups play an important role in substrate bonding on LF catalysts. We empirically consider that two key factors influence the hydrolysis reaction rate: substrate diffusion rate to active sites (k D) and surface reaction rate (k R). The k D depends on relative size of pore and substrate, and catalyst particle size. The k R depends on the type, concentration and distribution of acid sites. If k R ≫ k D, surface reaction is negligible and the reaction is diffuse-controlled, on the contrary, it is surface reaction-controlled and the pore has no effect on reaction rate. Although pore diameters of these LF catalysts are different, reactions over these catalysts harvest approximate amount of glucose in 4–7h (Fig. S2), indicating that the reaction over the LF catalysts is not diffuse-controlled in a long run. Actually, independent of synthetic ways, all catalysts have identical surface acid groups and thus will offer similar catalytic activities. As shown in Fig. S2, the reactions reach to 90% yield in 4h. Further increase in reaction time to 7h slightly increases yields to about 95%. Some studies found that glucose was not stable and was converted to other products [30,33]. But this study shows that glucose yields do not decrease with increase in reaction time, indicating glucose is stable in the system. 3.5 Conversion of polysaccharides to monosaccharides Catalytic hydrolysis of various glycosidic bonds in various polysaccharides over LF catalysts is shown in Table 2 . Maltose, linked by α-1,4 glycosidic bond, is converted to glucose in yields>90%. LF-A shows slightly better results than the other two catalysts. A possible reason is that LF-A inhibited the side reactions of glucose. d-Melezitose is a trisaccharide sugar with two glycosidic bonds. In theory one molar d-melezitose is hydrolyzed to two molar glucoses and one molar fructose. Catalytic results show that d-melezitose is converted to glucose in 91% yield and to fructose in 13–55% yield over the three catalysts. The fructose yields increase at LF-A<LF-B<LF-C. We think that fructose is easily isomerized to byproducts like 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (5-HMF) in narrow pore. 5-HMF was detected in d-melezitose hydrolysis. In the presence of the LF-A catalyst, sucrose, starch and inulin are converted to monosaccharides. The glucose yield is higher than fructose yield in sucrose hydrolysis. A control reaction of mixing glucose and catalyst under identical reaction conditions gave no product, but fructose is transformed to 5-HMF [34,35]. Mass transfer resistance and rigid structure of insoluble or partially soluble cellulose will inhibit catalytic reaction. Conversions of either crystalline cellulose or milled cellulose are sluggish with about 20% glucose yield (Table 2). We think that although mechanical milling can partially break crystalline cellulose to micrometer-scale particle, its size is still too bulky for being closely adsorbed on active sites. Less than 10% yield of glucose is obtained from Kimwipe filter paper and corn cob, both of which are insoluble in water. Ethyl cellulose is not converted at all. The substituted ethyl groups may hinder surface acidic sites access to glycosidic bonds and hydroxyl bonds, and thus inhibit the hydrolysis of ethyl cellulose. This reaction support our postulation that GBH reactions over the LF catalysts are catalyzed by catalytic and binding domains composed of SO3H, COOH and OH, not by SO3H itself. 3.6 Catalyst reusability A hot filtration test found that the conversion of cellobiose slightly increased, which could be attributed to the residue of LF catalyst or to the leaching of sulfonic acid, caused by incomplete condensation. N2 adsorption isotherm test showed that the used catalyst partially lost its porosity, which could be due to carbon deposit in recycling reactions. The durability of the LF-A catalysts was then examined by reusing four times in cellobiose hydrolysis. The catalyst was recovered by filtration after hydrolysis, washed, dried overnight, and reused in the next batch of hydrolysis. As shown in Fig. 6 , the catalyst remained comparable activity and selectivity after recycling four times. 3.7 Kinetic analysis Given the large excess of water in the system, kinetic parameters were calculated for LF-A assuming a rate expression that was first order in the cellobiose concentration using the reaction data from the three different temperatures (130, 140 and 150̊C). This assumption was consistent with previous reports on disaccharide and oligosaccharide hydrolysis [22,32,34]. Fig. 7 shows kinetic analysis result and Arrhenius plot. The apparent activation energy of cellobiose hydrolysis is 98.5kJmol−1. The value is smaller than 110–138kJmol−1 for cellobiose hydrolysis catalyzed by mineral acids, organic acid homogeneous catalysts [3,32]. We note that respecting the complexity of catalysis invoked in the catalytic system, more in-depth investigations are required in material synthesis and catalytic reactions. 4 Conclusions We have demonstrated that the condensation of lignosulfonate and formaldehyde generated a solid that contained SO3H, COOH and OH groups. The solid material exhibited high activity in the hydrolysis of polysaccharides to monosaccharides. Better accessibility of cellobiose to SO3H sites and multiple binding of hydroxyls of cellobiose on COOH and OH sites may respond for the increased activity compared with other acid catalysts. Kinetic analysis showed that the apparent activation energy over lignosulfonate-based catalyst is 98.5kJmol−1. The durability of the catalysts was examined by reusing four times in cellobiose hydrolysis. This is a cheap and facile way of making full use of industrial waste into valuable products. In light of its multifunctionalities, we hope this material can be used for other catalytic reactions, adsorption and ion-exchanged process.
